title: Deep Vein Thrombosis and Pulmonary Embolism
setup_script: A 45-year-old woman one week post total knee replacement presents with swelling and pain in her left calf. She reports shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain started today. She is on prophylactic low-molecular-weight heparin.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks for vital signs
dynamic_flow.reply: BP 110/70 mmHg, HR 115 bpm, RR 24/min, Temp 37.2 C, SpO2 90% on RA.
Left calf circumference increased compared with right; tender to palpation, Homan's sign positive; lungs clear; tachycardic.
D-dimer elevated at 2.0 ug/mL, CBC normal, creatinine 1.0 mg/dL.
Venous duplex ultrasound reveals occlusive thrombus in popliteal vein; CT pulmonary angiography shows segmental pulmonary emboli.
Start therapeutic heparin infusion transitioning to oral anticoagulation.
Reserved for hemodynamic instability; patient stable so anticoagulation alone.
Evaluate for recent surgery, bleeding risk; consider IVC filter if anticoagulation contraindicated.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident educates patient about symptoms of PE
dynamic_flow.reply: Discuss chest pain, dyspnea, seek immediate care if recurrent.
3 months anticoagulation for provoked DVT; extended if risk factors persist.
Only if unprovoked or recurrent events.
Evaluate PESI score; patient low risk so treat with close monitoring.
Early mobilization, mechanical prophylaxis and proper dosing of chemoprophylaxis in postoperative patients.

critical_decision_points: Recognizing signs of DVT and PE
Initiation of therapeutic anticoagulation and risk stratification
Recognition of indications for thrombolysis or IVC filter
Patient education on signs, symptoms and prevention

anchors.description: Fails to consider venous thromboembolism or misattributes symptoms to unrelated diagnoses.
Delayed or incomplete differential diagnosis; overlooks key features of venous thromboembolism
Recognizes venous thromboembolism as a possibility but omits important alternative diagnoses.
Develops a comprehensive differential including venous thromboembolism and systematically rules out other causes.
Quickly identifies venous thromboembolism as the leading diagnosis and articulates a complete differential with supporting and refuting data.
Fails to recognize patient instability or need for timely intervention.
Recognizes urgency but delays critical actions or orders inappropriate tests.
Initiates basic work-up and management but misses key steps or timing.
Prioritizes resuscitation, diagnostic testing and definitive therapy appropriately with good timing.
Displays superb judgement by anticipating complications, coordinating multidisciplinary care and making timely decisions.
Communication is disorganized, confusing, or lacks empathy toward the patient and team.
Provides information but lacks clarity, structure or fails to engage patient/team.
Clear communication of findings and plans but misses opportunities to confirm understanding.
Communicates clearly, logically and empathetically with patient and interdisciplinary team.
Exemplary communication: succinct, compassionate and anticipates information needs of patient and team.
Lacks understanding of the operative or procedural management for venous thromboembolism.
Identifies operative option for venous thromboembolism but with major gaps in technique or indications.
Describes the key operative steps with minor omissions or uncertainties.
Completely describes operative management, potential complications and alternatives for venous thromboembolism.
Demonstrates mastery of current evidence, operative nuances and peri-operative considerations for venous thromboembolism.
Displays disrespect, breaches patient confidentiality or fails to recognize limitations.
Inconsistent respect or lapses in accountability and honesty.
Maintains respect and integrity but requires prompting for self-reflection.
Consistently respectful, accountable and receptive to feedback.
Role model for professionalism, demonstrating humility, cultural sensitivity and ethical behavior.

rubric.resident_feedback_template: You correctly identified venous thromboembolism and initiated treatment. Continue refining your understanding of when to use thrombolysis or IVC filters and counseling patients on preventive measures.
